The term “title pages” should be understood very broadly here. Anything that has a title has a title page, even if that “page” consists of only a single heading.. Any templates provided in v:templatesvariablev:templates will be used preferentially to whatever builtin templates exist.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable is part of the experimental themes feature. It enumerates the available themes. Each theme has three parts, a name, an ID, and (optionally) an indication of whether or not it’s a “dark” theme.
Themes are implemented in CSS. If the theme-pickerparamtheme-picker is enabled, it will be possible for the reader to select a theme. The theme names are used for this purpose.
The ID value is used as a class on the html element. Everything else about the theme is implemented in CSS. To add a new theme, provide a set of CSS rules that apply when the ID class is in effect.

The dark mode setting is only used as a default. If the document does not specify a default-themeparamdefault-theme, if the user has never selected a theme, if the user has enabled dark mode at the operating system level, and if the browser makes this fact available, the first “dark” theme will automatically be selected.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Titles are complicated. They occur all over the place (on books, on chapters, on sections, on figures, on formal paragraphs, etc.) and they need to be rendered differently in different contexts. You are always free to write your own templates to completely customize the formatting, but the stylesheets provide five declarative properties that you can select for each title. As long as your formatting requirements are satisfied by these properties, you don’t have two write custom templates to do the formatting.
The properties are label, number, number format, inherit, and “label-toc”. Consider the title in .

mediaobject.alt: Illustration of title properties in a section title.

textobject.para: This image shows the title “Section 3.4 Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “3.” as the inherited number.

refsection.para: For any title context, identified by an XPath expression, you can set the label and number properties to specify whether or not those elements should appear. If inherit is true, the number of the parent element is included (so the figure might be section 4 in chapter 3, for example). The number-format property determines what style of numeration is used (arabic, lower- or upper-alpha, or lower- or upper-roman, for example).

The last property, label-toc, determines whether or not the label appears in the table of contents. This can be used, for example, to suppress the label “Figure” at the beginning of every figure in a list of figures.

The stylesheets search this list sequentially and the first match is used. Observe that v:user-title-propertiesvariablev:user-title-properties always comes first; if you want to override the default values, you can put your overrides in there. You do not have to redefine the entire list.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Title pages, taken loosely to mean anything with a title, are formatted using templates, see . If a template doesn’t exist for a particular context, the v:titlepage-defaultvariablev:titlepage-default template is used.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The contents of this variable will be rendered as the “close” icon for the persistent ToC.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The contents of this variable will be rendered as the “open” icon for the persistent ToC.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of known measurement units and their sizes

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The v:unit-scalevariablev:unit-scale map contains a set of measurement units and their absolute length in terms of pixels (as computed with pixels-per-inchparampixels-per-inch).
Recognized units at the time of this writing are shown in .
See also .

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable contains user-supplied overrides to v:title-propertiesvariablev:title-properties. See that variable for more details.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable contains user-supplied overrides to v:xref-propertiesvariablev:xref-properties. See that variable for more details.

refnamediv.refpurpose: A list determining how callouts are processed

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This value is a sequence constructed automatically from the verbatim-calloutsparamverbatim-callouts parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of verbatim elements to be rendered in the line style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements whose local names appear in this list will be formatted using the line verbatim style by default. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This list is usually constructed from the verbatim-line-styleparamverbatim-line-style parameter.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, every verbatim-number-every-nthparamverbatim-number-every-nth line is numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-every-nthparamverbatim-number-every-nth parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Always number the first line of a verbatim listing?

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, the first line will be numbered (irrespective of the setting of v:verbatim-number-every-nthvariablev:verbatim-number-every-nth if this value is true.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-first-lineparamverbatim-number-first-line parameter.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting verbatim environments with line numbers, environments less than verbatim-number-minlinesparamverbatim-number-minlines in length will not be numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-number-minlinesparamverbatim-number-minlines parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Identifies verbatim elements that should have line numbers

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A list of the verbatim environments that should be numbered.
This value is usually constructed from the verbatim-numbered-elementsparamverbatim-numbered-elements parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: List of verbatim elements to be rendered in the plain style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements whose local names appear in this list will be formatted using the plain verbatim style by default. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This list is usually constructed from the verbatim-plain-styleparamverbatim-plain-style parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Controls the verbatim properties of an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When processing a verbatim environment, this array of maps is consulted to determine what properties apply to the verbatim environment. Most simple, global customizations of verbatim environments can be achieved by setting the verbatim-line-styleparamverbatim-line-style, verbatim-plain-styleparamverbatim-plain-style, verbatim-calloutsparamverbatim-callouts, and verbatim-numbered-elementsparamverbatim-numbered-elements parameters.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The space character to use when padding verbatim lines

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When a verbatim line has to be padded in order to get a callout to appear in the correct column, this character will be used as the padding character. For a discussion of verbatim elements and styles, see .
This character is usually constructed from the verbatim-spaceparamverbatim-space parameter. Unlike the verbatim-spacevariableverbatim-space, this variable must be a node not a string.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Languages for which syntax highlighting should be performed

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The verbatim-syntax-highlight-languagesparamverbatim-syntax-highlight-languages is a single string for the convenience of users. This variable contains the languages as a list.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the Pygments Pygments Syntax highlightingPygments syntax highlighter is applied, the verbatim-syntax-highlight-optionsvariableverbatim-syntax-highlight-options are applied.
Three options are recognized:

listitem.para: The programming language to use for syntax highlighting. This option is required.
If the show-command option is true (“1”, “yes”, or “true”), then the pygmentize command will be printed. This is a debugging option.
If the show-result option is true (“1”, “yes”, or “true”), then the string returned from pygmentize will be printed. This is a debugging option.

note.para: Syntax highlighting with Pygments requires spawning an external process for each highlighted environment. This can add significantly to the processing time if there are many such environments.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the Pygments Pygments Syntax highlightingPygments syntax highlighter is applied, the verbatim-syntax-highlight-pygments-optionsvariableverbatim-syntax-highlight-pygments-options are applied.
Each key/value pair in the map will be passed to pygmentize as a -Pkey=value option.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This variable holds the version number of the stylesheets.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Generally speaking the VERSIONvariableVERSION is sufficient to identify the stylesheets. The VERSION-IDvariableVERSION-ID adds a unique identifier derived from the latest git commit.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Cross-references, like title properties, are complicated. They can occur almost anywhere and several styles are possible.

mediaobject.alt: Illustration of cross-reference properties in a numbered section reference

textobject.para: This image shows the cross-reference “Section 3.4, Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “, ” as number separator and “Changing the print head” as the title.

refsection.para: For documents with numbered sections, a style such as the one shown in is common. Here the label, number, and title are sufficient.

mediaobject.alt: Illustration of cross-reference properties in an unnumbered section reference

textobject.para: This image shows the title “Section 3.4 Changing the print head” identifying “Section” as the label, “3.4” as the number, and “3.” as the inherited number.

refsection.para: For documents without section numbers, a different approach is required. In , we see how a prefix (which can be literal text or a key into a localization) precedes the title. If an inherit reference is defined, the cross reference will include a reference to that element as well. A separator can be placed between them. If the format for the inherited reference also specifies an inherited reference, the process will continue.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the absolute length of a unit of measurement

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: For a given unit of measurement, returns the absolute length in terms of pixels. For a discussion of units, see .
See also pixels-per-inchvariablepixels-per-inch, default-length-magnitudevariabledefault-length-magnitude, and default-length-unitvariabledefault-length-unit.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the attribute that apply to an output element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Most output elements have attributes: any xml:id attributes in the source are reflected in the output as id attributes, most elements get a class attribute, etc. The f:attributes function is called to determine what those attributes should be.
In practice, the way this usually works is the element is processed in the m:attributes mode and that template calls f:attributes to generate the actual attribute nodes.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the “colsep” value associated with a CALS table cell

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The column separator, or “colsep”, associated with a CALS table cell depends on a variety of factors: colspec, and spanspec elements as well as the attributes on the cell itself and its ancestors.
This function returns the value that applies to the specified cell.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the “rowsep” value associated with a CALS table cell

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The row separator, or “rowsep”, associated with a CALS table cell depends on a variety of factors: colspec, and spanspec elements as well as the attributes on the cell itself and its ancestors.
This function returns the value that applies to the specified cell.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Like f:gentext, this function returns the generated text appropriate for its arguments. However, if there is no appropriate generated text, this function returns an empty sequence without generating any warning messages.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the db-chunk and perhaps other chunking-related attributes for the given node.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the filename to use for a particular chunk

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When chunking, see , this function is called to determine the filename for a chunk. The default implementation considers relevant dbdb processing instruction processing instructions (filename db processing instruction annotations pseudo-attribute , href db processing instruction annotations pseudo-attribute , and basename db processing instruction annotations pseudo-attribute pseudo-attributes) as well as the generated ID of the element.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the title of a chunk

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When the title of a neighboring chunk is required (for header or footer navigation, for example), this function can be used to obtain the title of that chunk.
This function must return the HTML-formatted title, not the DocBook title.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns a length in the format of a CSS property

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the CSS property specified with the corresponding length, if the length exists. Returns the empty sequence otherwise.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns a CSS property for a given value

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the specified value exists, a string formatted as a CSS property is returned. If the value doesn’t exist, an empty sequence is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the format string for a date

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Dates may be stored in a variety of formats and the pubdate element even allows inline markup. The f:date-format function determines how a date will be formatted:

listitem.para: If the date contains embedded markup, the special value “apply-templates” is returned to indicate that string formatting isn’t appropriate.
If the date conforms to an date, the date-date-formatparamdate-date-format string is returned.
If the date conforms to an dateTime, the date-dateTime-formatparamdate-dateTime-format string is returned.
If the date does not conform to either of those date formats, “apply-templates” is returned.

refsection.para: If the date conforms to a date or dateTime, the author may override the format string by providing a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a date-format db processing instruction date-format pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute.
shows an example of several dates that may be formatted in more familiar forms.

example.title: Several dates in ISO 8601 formats
example.programlisting: <para>The Unix epoch begins at <date>1970-01-01T00:00:00Z</date>. Grace Hopper was born on <date>1906-12-09</date>. That was a <date><?db date-format="[F]"?>1906-12-09</date>. I was born on a <date>Friday</date>.</para>

refsection.para: With default formats, these are formatted as shown:

informalfigure.para: The Unix epoch begins at 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z. Grace Hopper was born on 1906-12-09. That was a 1906-12-09. I was born on a Friday.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns a map that represents an empty length

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Lengths are compound objects. Lengths consist of a magnitude (a number) and a unit: 3 inches, for example, or 11.9 barleycorns in the case of absolute lengths. For relative lengths, the unit is something relative like percent.
These are represented as maps internally and f:empty-length returns a length with no magnitude or units.

annotation.para: Yes, that’s a real unit. It’s equal to ⅓ of an inch. I’ll leave it to Wikipedia to explain the details. Just looking at the chart of imperial units makes me want to add them all!

textobject.para: A graph showing the derivations of English imperial measurements: 12 inches to the foot, 3 feet to the yard, etc.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns true if two lengths are equal

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Lengths (see ) are stored in maps and so are not directly comparable. This function returns true if two lengths are equal.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate a unique identifier for an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a unique ID for an element. The ID is generated from the names of the ancestors and preceding siblings of the element. This value will be consistent across different transformations as long as the ancestors and preceding siblings remain unchanged.

If use-xml-id is true and there’s an element with a xml:id attribute among the ancestors, the unique identifier is rooted at that element, rather than traversing all the way to the root of the document.
Disabling this feature by setting use-xml-id to false allows for the creation of globally unique IDs with f:unique-id.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the generated text associated with the specified key in the specified context for the specified node. If key is not provided, the element name of the node is used.

For example, if the f:language of the $node is English, then in the “title” context, the generated text for the key “tableofcontents” is “Table of Contents”. If the language is French, then the generated text is “Table des matières”.
The contexts and the keys are defined in the locale files.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the letters for the in-scope language

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function works calls f:language on the specified node and then calls f:gentext-letters-for-language with that language.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the letters for a language

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns a language-specific list of letters. These are used, for example, to construct the divisions in an index.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns true if the specified verbatim environment should have syntax highlighting applied to it. This depends on the language specified on the environment and the verbatim-syntax-highlight-languagesparamverbatim-syntax-highlight-languages parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the href link to a node

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function generates a value for an HTML href attribute at the position of the context that will link to the node.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an ID for the element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the ID of the element. If the element has an xml:id attribute, the value of that attribute is returned. Otherwise, the function constructs a unique ID value for the element.

The simplest way to construct a unique ID is with the f:generate-id function. However, those values are only unique within the context of a single transformation and tend to vary over time. This can break anchors used in published documents and leads to spurious differences between documents.
The stylesheets generate their own unique IDs with f:generate-id.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When a compound number appears in a title, this function is used to obtain the intra number separator. The most common separator is “.” which results in numbers such as “Section 3.4”. If the function returned “*”, the section title would be rendered as “Section 3*4”.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Tests if a length is empty

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns true if the length is empty. For a discussion of units and lengths, see .

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determines if a given value represents “true”

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: There are several conventions for indicating “true” or “false”. XSLT uses the words “yes” and “no” in many places. The XML Schema data type for xs:boolean uses “true” and “false” but also “1” and “0”.

The f:is-true function returns true() for any of “true()”, “yes”, “true”, or a value that can be cast to an integer if that integer is not zero. It returns false() for any of “false()”, “no”, “false”, a value that can be cast to an integer that is zero, or the empty sequence.
It reports an error for any other value and returns “true()”.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the best matching localization language

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the localization language that best matches the language of the $target node. The default language will be returned if there is no localization available for that language.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The label separator separates a label from the number or title that follows it.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the language associated with an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the value of the nearest in-scope xml:lang attribute or default-languageparamdefault-language if no such attribute exists.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the string representation of a length

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: For a given length (see ), returns the relative or absolute length formatted as a string. Relative lengths are formatted as the length followed by a literal “*” (e.g., “3*”). Absolute lengths are formatted as the length followed by the unit (e.g., “2.54cm”).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the units associated with a length

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: For a given length (see ), returns the units associated with the length. Returns an empty sequence for relative lengths.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Construct a length from constituent parts

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: These functions construct a length (see ) from either a relative magnitude, an absolute magnitude and a unit, or both.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The number separator separates a number (in a title) from the title that follows it.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the alignment of a media object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: By default, this function simply returns the value of the object’s align attribute.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the content height of an object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the content height, for reasons of historical accident, in the contentdepth attribute. This function returns the height of an object as a length (see ), if it has one. If the height is specified as a percentage, and the intrinsic size of the object is known, the an absolute length equal to that percentage of the intrinsic size is returned.
If image-ignore-scalingparamimage-ignore-scaling is true, or no contentdepth is specified for the object, the empty sequence is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the content width of an object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the content width. This function returns the width of an object as a length (see ), if it has one. If the width is specified as a percentage, and the intrinsic size of the object is known, the an absolute length equal to that percentage of the intrinsic size is returned.
If image-ignore-scalingparamimage-ignore-scaling is true, or no contentwidth is specified for the object, the empty sequence is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the height (depth) of a mediaobject

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The height of a mediaobject is specified, for reasons of historical accident, in the depth attribute. This function returns the height of an object as a length (see ), if it has one. If image-ignore-scalingparamimage-ignore-scaling is true, or no depth is specified for the object, the empty sequence is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the properties of an object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If the extension functions are available, the stylesheets will interrogate images for their properties. The goal is to return, at a minimum, the height and width of the image. This is used to compute viewport and scaling factors. If the image metadata extension is available, then considerably more information my be returned in the map.
For example, the image metadata properties of the Amaryllis photograph in are:

textobject.para: Several rich, red amaryllis blossoms on a black background.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the scaling factor for an object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the scaling factor for an object. Scaling only applies if image-ignore-scalingparamimage-ignore-scaling is false and the object has a scale attribute.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function determines whether or not an object should be scaled to fit its container.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the vertical alignment of a media object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: By default, this function simply returns the value of the object’s valign attribute. If it doesn’t have a valign attribute, the value “middle” is returned, because that’s what previous versions of stylesheets for DocBook did.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the width of a mediaobject

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns the width of an object as a length (see ), if it has one. If image-ignore-scalingparamimage-ignore-scaling is true, or no width is specified for the object, the empty length is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the item numeration format for an ordered list

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Computes the numeration for the specified list item. See orderedlist-item-numerationparamorderedlist-item-numeration.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the item number of an item in an ordered list

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the item number of a list item. This is always an integer, even if it will be formatted as a letter, roman numeral, or other symbol. For nested lists, this function returns the fully qualified item number. For example, for the second item in the fourth item in the third item of a list, it will return (2, 4, 3).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the starting number of an ordered list

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: In most orderedlist elements, the first item in the list is item number “1”. However, the startingnumber attribute can specify a different initial number and, in the case of continued lists, the starting number depends on the ending number of the preceding list.
The f:orderedlist-startingnumber returns the number of the first list item in an ordered list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Parse a string into a length

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function parses a string such as “4in” or “3.14cm” or “50%” into a length. It will fall back to a distance of the default-length-magnitudeparamdefault-length-magnitude and default-length-unitparamdefault-length-unit if the string cannot be parsed as a length.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Several DocBook elements have alternate presentations that can be specified with global parameters. Many of them can also be set on a per-element basis with a db db processing instruction processing instruction. The date format, for example, can be changed in this way as described in the f:date-format function.

The f:pi function takes a context and the name of a property. It returns the value specified for that property from all of the db processing instructions in the specified context. The three argument version allows you to specify a default value. It will be returned if there are no values specified for the property in that context.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Using pseudo-attributes in a db db processing instruction processing instruction is a convenient mechanism for providing additional options to the stylesheets. But processing them is tedious. This function gathers together the pseudo-attributes specified in a series of processing instructions and returns them as attributes on an element. If the same property occurs more than once in the sequence, the last value will be returned.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Titles consist of an optional label, followed by an optional number, followed by the title. In some contexts, additional prefixes and suffixes may also be involved. In the title “Chapter 1 Introduction”, the word “Chapter” is the label, “1” is the number, and “Introduction” is the title.
When a label appears in a title, the f:post-label-punctuation function determines what punctuation, if any, should follow it.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Is this a section in a refentry?

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns true if the node is a section in a refentry, a refsection, refsect1, refsect2, or refsect3 element.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the relative portion of a length, if it has one

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: For a given length, returns the relative length if it has one. For lengths that have no relative component, returns 0.0. For a discussion of units, see .

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the (relative) path to a mediaobject

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Working out the correct URI for a media objects (images, videos, audio) can be quite complicated. For the author, it may be useful or necessary that the URI in the fileref attribute correctly point to the object at authoring time. But that URI may not be correct for the generated HTML. In particular, authors may put source files in different directories, media objects may be stored in a common location for several documents even though those documents are published in different locations, etc.
The f:resolve-object-uri takes the URI of the media object as it appears in the source and attempts to resolve that into an appropriate URI for the generated HTML.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns true if the node is a section, a section or sect1-5 element.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the section depth of a node

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the section depth of a node, that is, how many section elements are among its ancestors.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Select a media object for presentation

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function takes a sequence of media objects (imageobject, videoobject, etc.) and returns one for presentation. It processes each element in m:acceptable-mediaobject mode. If at least one object is deemed acceptable, the first acceptable object is returned. If none are acceptable, the first object is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Selects an appropriate data element for a media object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Once a media object has been selected, one of its data elements has to be selected. This function is responsible for making that selection. It processes each of the data elements in m:acceptable-mediaobject-data mode and returns the first acceptable item.

If no acceptable items are found, the function will return the empty sequence if $force is false. If $force is true, the first data element will be returned, even though it was not deemed “acceptable”.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a string of $length spaces. If $length:

listitem.para: is empty, an empty sequence is returned.
is an integer, or castable to an integer, a string of that length is returned. If the length is negative, an empty sequence is returned.
is anything else, the length of the string value of $length is used as the length.

refsection.para: In other words:

listitem.para: f:spaces(()) is ‘()’,
f:spaces(0) is ‘’ (no spaces),
f:spaces(-1) is ‘()’,
f:spaces(2) is ‘ ’ (two spaces),
f:spaces("1") is ‘ ’ (one space), and
f:spaces("test") is ‘ ’ (four spaces).

refsection.para: This function accepts a sequence to support the empty sequence. If it’s passed a sequence of more than one item, it treats that as if the string values of the items had been concatenated together. This can have slightly surprising consequences as “('a', '3', '0')” will return a string of three spaces whereas “('0', '3', '0')” will return a string of thirty.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the step number of a step in an procedure

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the step number of step in a procedure. This is always an integer, even if it will be formatted as a letter, roman numeral, or other symbol. For steps nested in side substeps, this function returns the fully qualified item number. For example, for the second substep in the fourth substep in the third step of a procedure, it will return (2, 4, 3).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the step numeration format for a step

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Computes the numeration for the specified step. See procedure-step-numerationparamprocedure-step-numeration.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Verbatim environments that specify a language can be syntax highlighted. Syntax highlighting adds additional spans so that, for example, CSS can be used to make keyword bold or quoted strings a different color.
Syntax highlighting requires an extension function. The list of languages that will be syntax highlighted is taken from verbatim-syntax-highlight-languagesparamverbatim-syntax-highlight-languages.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the element identified by a particular id

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The item with the specified ID that is in the same document as $context item is returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the title page template for an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Returns the title page template that should be used for an element. If no template is found, returns the $default template.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Tokenize a string at a specific character

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function tokenizes a string at a specific character (not a regular expression). If the specified character is a regular expression meta-character, it is automatically escaped.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an ID for the element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function returns a globally unique ID for the element. This allows a transformation to disambiguate between different elements that happen to have the same xml:id, as can occur if transclusion is performed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the highlight properties for a verbatim environment

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Verbatim elements can be styled in a variety of ways, see . This function returns the highlight settings for a particular verbatim environment.

If the style for this environment is explicitly “plain”, then no highlight settings are returned (this avoids a bunch of warning messages). Otherwise, if a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a verbatim-highlight db processing instruction verbatim-highlight pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute is present, it is returned. If there’s no PI, then the default settings for this kind of environment are returned.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns true if the listing should be numbered

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The f:verbatim-numbered function returns true of the specified verbatim listing should be numbered. This will be true if:

listitem.para: The linenumbering attribute is specified and has the value numbered,
the element’s name is listed in verbatim-numbered-elementsparamverbatim-numbered-elements, or
a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a verbatim-numbered db processing instruction verbatim-numbered pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute that is true is specified.

refsection.para: There are two overriding conditions that will force the value to be false: first, if the linenumbering attribute is specified and has the value unnumbered, the listing will not be numbered. Second if the listing has a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a verbatim-style db processing instruction verbatim-style pseudo-attribute pseudo attribute that specifies the “plain” style. Listings in the plain style cannot be numbered, attempting to do so will generate a warning message from the stylesheets.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the style of a verbatim listing

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The f:verbatim-style function returns the style of presentation that should be used for the specified verbatim listing.

If a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a verbatim-style db processing instruction verbatim-style pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute is present, the value of that pseudo-attribute will be returned. Otherwise, it will be “lines” if the element’s name is listed in verbatim-line-styleparamverbatim-line-style, “plain” if the element’s name is listed in verbatim-plain-styleparamverbatim-plain-style, or “raw”.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return true if trailing blank lines should be trimmed

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This function examines a verbatim environment, the $context, and returns true if trailing blank lines should be trimmed from it. A dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with a verbatim-trim-trailing db processing instruction verbatim-trim-trailing pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute may be used to override the verbatim-trim-trailing-blank-linesparamverbatim-trim-trailing-blank-lines parameter on a case-by-case basis.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the XLink style for this document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The stylesheets support XLink extended links. See xlink-styleparamxlink-style for more details.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Parses an XPointer for a same-document ID reference

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: In DocBook, there are generally two ways to refer to other elements in the current document by ID: using the linkend (or linkends) attribute or using the xlink:href attribute.
The f:xpointer-idref function returns the ID portion of an XPointer that is a reference to another ID in the current document.
In other words:

listitem.para: f:xpointer-idref('#foo') is foo,
f:xpointer-idref('id(foo)') is foo,
and f:xpointer-idref('http://example.org/#foo') is the empty sequence.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This extension function returns the current working directory from which the processor was executed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return intrinsic properties of an image

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This extension function returns a map of metadata properties about the image, including its intrinsic size: its width and height in pixels. If the size can be determined, the map returned will have a “width” key whose value is the width of the image and a “height” key whose value is the height of the image. Both sizes will be integer values.
This function uses the library. The map may contain other properties as well.

listitem.para: If the media was successfully parsed with metadata-extractor, all of the properties identified by the extractor will be returned. Each property name will be converted to lowercase and spaces will be replaced with hyphens. (In other words, a property with the tag name “Palette Colour Count” will appear in the map with a key of “palette-colour-count”.)

Property values that appear to be data/time values
A value that matches the regular expression “^\d\d\d\d:\d\d:\d\d \d\d:\d\d:\d\d$” is assumed to be a date/time. This is the format of date/time values used in EXIF metadata for most properties that have a date/time value. will be converted to strings that are valid ISO 8601 date/time values. Any control characters that can’t appear in XML but that appear in a value will be replaced with Unicode references, \uxxxx. For example, a null byte will be replaced with \u0000.
If the media isn’t successfully parsed with metadata-extractor,

If it appears to be a PDF document, the function will search for the “MediaBox” or “CropBox” in the first 100 lines of the PDF. If either is found, its dimensions are used to calculate the width and height. If both are present, CropBox is preferred.

If it appears to be an SVG document, the function will search for width and height attributes on the root element. All of the attributes of the root element will be returned as properties, using Clark names.

refsection.para: If the width and height properties exist, they will always be integers. This means that if an image has a property with the name width or height and its value isn’t an integer, it will not be returned.
If the debugparamdebug parameter includes the token image-properties, the stylesheets will print every property returned in an xsl:message.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Return intrinsic properties of an image

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This extension function returns the intrinsic size of an image: its width and height in pixels. If the size can be determined, the map returned will have a “width” key whose value is the width of the image and a “height” key whose value is the height of the image. Both sizes will be integral numbers of pixels.
The ext:image-metadata function provides better results. It should be preferred unless the libraries are unavailable.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Syntax highlight a listing with pygmentize

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This extension function runs the pygmentize command to add syntax highlighting to a listing.

The second argument can either be map, in which case the key-value pairs of the map constitute the options, or it can be a single string. If it’s a single string, it’s interpreted as if it was a map with the key “language” and the string as the value.
The third argument must be a map. Each key-value pair will be passed to pygmentize as “-Pkey=value”.
The function returns the string output from pygmentize. It must be parsed with parse-xml if you wish to process it as XML.

Be aware that pygmentize strips leading blank lines off of the source listing. If you’re selecting portions of a listing with XInclude, make sure not to select leading blank lines in the listing if you are trying to accurately count the lines.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns true if pygmentize is available

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: In order to run Pygments on listings, the ext:pygmentize extension function must be available and the pygmentize command must be available on the host system.
This function returns true if it successfully finds the pygmentize command on the system path.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Performs XInclude processing on node and all of its descendants. The options “fixup-xml-base” and “fixup-xml-lang” are true() by default.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This extension function validates the node provided against the schema. The schema can be either a string (the URI of the RELAX NG grammar file) or a node (a RELAX NG grammar document). There is no support for the RELAX NG Compact Syntax at this time.
The available options are assert-valid which defaults to true() and dtd-compatibility which isn’t actually supported yet.
If assert-valid is true() and the document is not valid according to the grammar provided, an exception is raised.
If assert-valid is false(), or the document is valid, the map returned will contain the following keys:

listitem.para: A boolean indicating whether or not the document was valid.
The validated document. Today, this always returns the same node, but it may eventually return an augmented document.
An array of maps containing the type (warning, error, or fatal-error), message, line, and column where an error occurred. If the document is valid, the errors key will not be present.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Unlike bibliomixed, where the author is expected to provide most of the formatting, biblioentry is a bag of metadata. On the one hand, this opens up the possibility of producing different bibliographic styles from the same entry. On the other hand, it greatly complicates formatting.
The default t:biblioentry template uses a header template (see ).

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This template generates the bottom-of-page nav element. When chunking is performed, this should provide links between pages.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Cleanup the HTML markup for a DocBook document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode performs cleanup tasks on the HTML document that results from calling t:process. This process moves footnotes and annotations when necessary, generates navigation elements, etc.

Most customizations can simply call t:docbook; you only need to call the t:preprocess, t:process, t:postprocess (or t:chunk-cleanup and t:chunk-output) if you need to perform very specialized cleanup tasks.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When chunking is being performed (see ), all of the footnotes that should appear in a chunk are processed with this template.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate chunked output for a DocBook document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode processes the persistent-tocparampersistent-toc if requested and generates individual documents for each chunk. Like the XPath transform function, this template returns a map. You must process the map to store the documents.

Most customizations can simply call t:docbook; you only need to call the t:preprocess, t:process, t:postprocess (or t:chunk-output and t:chunk-output) if you need to perform very specialized cleanup tasks.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode processes a DocBook document. It runs the t:preprocess template to normalize the source, processes the normalized source in the m:docbook mode with the t:process template, and runs the t:postprocess template to clean up the HTML and generate the chunks (if necessary).

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This template is called when an empty index tag is found the document and automatic index generation is enabled. Automatic index generation is enabled if either the generate-indexparamgenerate-index is true or a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction with an autoindex db processing instruction autoindex pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute is true. If the autoindex pseudo-attribute is explicitly false, automatic index generation is suppressed for the index in which it appears.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Process image map areas in an imageobjectco

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If callouts are provided for an image with imageobjectco, the t:imagemap template is called to transform the areas into an HTML image map.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This template is called to generate index references for terms that have a zone attribute. It is only called when generating an index.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: All of the inline elements are processed by t:inline. This provides a common place to handle the fact that any of them might be a link. Several parameters exist to handle variations in presentation:

listitem.para: Maps the element to a particular HTML element. Defaults to span.
A list of tokens that should be added to the element’s class attribute.
If this is true, the local name of the DocBook element being processed will be added to the classes.
The element content. By default, this is obtained by applying XSLT templates to the element’s content.
Extra attributes to be added to the element.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This template formats a personal name according to the specified style. This template must only be called when the current context item is a personname. The personname element can be used in two different ways, it can just contain the name:
or it can contain the name with markup:
How the name is formatted depends on which form of markup is used and which style is selected. Several styles are supported:

listitem.para: If the name contains no markup, it is simply formatted as is.
If the style is “FAMILY-given”, it is formatted with t:person-name-family-given and generally produces the family name in upper case followed by the given name. For example: “WALSH Norman”.
If the style is “last-first”, it is formatted with t:person-name-last-first and generally produces the family name followed by the given name separated by a comma. For example: “Walsh, Norman”.
If the style is “first-last”, it is formatted with t:person-name-first-last and generally produces the given name followed by the family name. For example: “Norman Walsh”.
Any other value raises dbe:INVALID-NAME-STYLE.

note.title: Given names
note.para: Historically, DocBook used firstname for the given name of a person. In DocBook 5.1, the givenname element was introduced as an alternative. The stylesheets treat them identically.

refsection.para: The stylesheets attempt to determine what style to use for each personname:

listitem.para: First, by looking at that the role attribute on that element. If any of styles from the v:personal-name-stylesvariablev:personal-name-styles list appear in the role, that style will be selected. (If more than one style appears, the results are undefined.)
If the personname doesn’t identify a style, and if it’s a child of author, editor, or othercredit, the role attirbute of its parent is inspected.
If a style still hasn’t been selected and the in-context language localization file contains a “personname” key, the value of that key is taken as the style.
Failing all those options, the default-personal-name-styleparamdefault-personal-name-style is selected.
for a given name,
for a family name,
for lineage (such as “Jr” or “III”),
for an honorific title (such as “Dr” or “Ms”), and
for everything else.

refsection.para: In all likelihood, if your document contains a variety of personal names, you will need to use roles to disambiguate special cases and you will have to provide alternate or additional templates to format them.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats a personal name in the “FAMILY-given” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The “FAMILY-given” style formats a personal name as the family name (surname) in upper-case, followed by the first given name (if there is one), followed by the text “[FAMILY given]”. See t:person-name.
shows an example of a personal name to be formatted with the “FAMILY-given” style.
That would be formatted as:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats a personal name in the “first-last” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The “first-last” style formats a personal name as: the first honorific, followed by the given name, followed possibly by the “middle name”, followed by the surname, followed by the lineage. See t:person-name.
If an othername is provided and if othername-in-middleparamothername-in-middle is true, then the first othername will be treated as a “middle name” and presented between the given and family names.
shows an example of a personal name to be formatted with the “first-last” style.
That would be formatted as:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats a personal name in the “last-first” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The “last-first” style formats a personal name as the family name (surname) followed by the first given name (if there is one). If both a family name and a given name are present, they are separated by a comma. See t:person-name.
shows an example of a personal name to be formatted with the “last-first” style.
That would be formatted as:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Formats a sequence of personal names

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Formats a sequence of names:

listitem.para: If the sequence consists of a single name, it is formatted.
If the sequence consists of exactly two names, they are formatted with “and” between them where “and” is taken from the in-scope language localization file. It is the item with the key “author-sep2”.

If the sequence consists of more than two names, all but the last are separated by “, “ (the localization item with the key “author-sep”). The last is separated by “, and” (the localization item with the key “author-seplast”).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Prepare a DocBook document for processing

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A lot of variation is possible in DocBook documents. In addition, the stylesheets have features that require combining several documents together (see bibliography-collectionparambibliography-collection, for example).
The t:preprocess template runs a pipeline of transformations that normalize the sources. This normalized source has much less variation which simplifies the templates used for main processing.
Most customizations can simply call t:docbook; you only need to call the t:preprocess, t:process, t:postprocess if you need to perform very specialized cleanup tasks.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode processes a normalized document. You must call t:preprocess before calling t:process or you will get erroneous results.
Most customizations can simply call t:docbook; you only need to call the t:preprocess, t:process, t:postprocess if you need to perform very specialized cleanup tasks.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode performs cleanup tasks on the HTML document that results from calling t:process by calling t:chunk-cleanup and t:chunk-output. This template returns a map.
Most customizations can simply call t:docbook; you only need to call the t:preprocess, t:process, t:postprocess if you need to perform very specialized cleanup tasks.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The t:table-footnotes template is called to process footnotes at the bottom of a table.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This template generates the top-of-page nav element. When chunking is performed, this should provide links between pages.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: In DocBook, most elements can be links. The t:xlink template is called for each element that might be participating in a link. This includes both simple links (any inline element with an xlink:href attribute) and extended links.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A mediaobject may contain several alternatives (different formats, for example, or different resolutions). The alternatives will be processed in the m:acceptable-mediaobject mode before presentation. This mode must either return the media object, if it’s appropriate for the rendering being produced, or the empty sequence, if it is not.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Selects media object data elements that may be used

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Like the m:acceptable-mediaobject mode, this mode is used to determine which alternative media objects (in the case of this mode, the media object data elements, such as imagedata) should be considered.
By default, this mode just compares the media object URI extension with the list of mediaobject-exclude-extensionsparammediaobject-exclude-extensions and rejects elements that have URIs that match.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for the content of annotations

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Annotations, like footnotes, have markers and wrappers that are necessary to support their presentation. The m:annotation-content mode is used to process the actual body of the annotation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing funcsynopsis elements in the “ANSI” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The funcsynopsis element has several possible renderings. This mode is used when the “ANSI” style of rendering has been selected and a non-tabular layout is being used.

See also: m:ansi-table, m:kr, m:kr-table, funcsynopsis-default-stylevariablefuncsynopsis-default-style, funcsynopsis-table-thresholdvariablefuncsynopsis-table-threshold, and funcsynopsis-trailing-punctuationvariablefuncsynopsis-trailing-punctuation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing funcsynopsis elements in the “ANSI” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The funcsynopsis element has several possible renderings. This mode is used when the “ANSI” style of rendering has been selected and a table will be used for layout.

See also: m:ansi, m:kr, m:kr-table, funcsynopsis-default-stylevariablefuncsynopsis-default-style, funcsynopsis-table-thresholdvariablefuncsynopsis-table-threshold, and funcsynopsis-trailing-punctuationvariablefuncsynopsis-trailing-punctuation.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Each DocBook element in the source document produces a primary HTML element in the result document. The attributes associated with that primary element are obtained by processing the DocBook element in the m:attributes mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing biblioentry bibliographic entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: DocBook bibliographic entries come in two forms: raw and cooked. The biblioentry form is the “raw” form. The m:biblioentry mode is used to process these elements.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing bibliomixed bibliographic entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: DocBook bibliographic entries come in two forms: raw and cooked. The bibliomixed form is the “cooked” form. The m:bibliomixed mode is used to process these elements.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Callouts are processed in this mode to produce the callout marks (or “bugs”) used to indicate cross references between the callouts and their corresponding areas. This mode should only produce the mark, for example “①”. See m:callout-link.

By default, callouts are numbered sequentially from 1 within each listing. However, a dbdb processing instruction processing instruction placed in the areaspec can specify a different starting number. If the starting-callout-number db processing instruction starting-callout-number pseudo-attribute pseudo-attribute is an integer, that’s used as the starting number. If it has the special value “continues”, then numbering continues sequentially after the last callout number used in the preceding verbatim listing.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Callouts in a calloutlist can link back to the corresponding point in the listing or on the image. This mode is used to produce those links.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Every HTML chunk is processed with the m:chunk-cleanup mode. This mode makes sure that footnotes and annotations appear in the chunks where their references appear, adds navigation to the top and bottom of each chunk, etc. See .

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Every element that is identified as a chunk, see , will be called in the m:chunk-filename mode to obtain the filename for that chunk.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Performs the final-pass of processing on chunks

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Chunks (see ) are constructed in several passes. The last pass is in the m:chunk-output mode. This mode makes last minute adjustments and produces the individual chunk documents.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generates the page title for the chunk

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The page title, the title in the HTML head, is generated by processing the heading in this mode. This mode is responsible for removing markup from the title.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When all of the chunk processing is finished, each chunk is processed in m:chunk-write mode. By default, this mode creates XSL result documents for each chunk.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The year elements in a copyright are processed in this mode. This mode handles the separation (and possible collapsing) of years.

See also copyright-year-range-separatorvariablecopyright-year-range-separator and copyright-year-separatorvariablecopyright-year-separator, and copyright-collapse-yearsvariablecopyright-collapse-years.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce a cross-reference to the element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref mode is used to generate a cross-reference.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-inherit-separator mode is used to generate the text that should follow the element when an inherited reference is used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce the label in a cross-reference

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-label mode is used to generate the label in a cross-reference.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-label-separator mode is used to generate the separator between a label and what follows it in a cross-reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce the number in a cross-reference

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-number mode is used to generate the number in a cross-reference.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-number-separator mode is used to generate the separator between a number and what follows it in a cross-reference.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-prefix mode is used to generate any text that precedes a cross reference.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-suffix mode is used to generate any text that follows a cross reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce the title in a cross-reference

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:crossref-title mode formats the title in a cross-reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce details about a media object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode is used to produce the details about a media object, such as a long description.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce the short summary for a media object

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode is used to produce a short detail summary about a media object. This is most often used as the alt text for the object.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The primary mode for processing DocBook elements

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:docbook mode is the primary mode for processing DocBook elements. Critically, this means that if you import the DocBook stylesheets and wish to override some of the templates, you must make sure that those templates are defined in the m:docbook mode.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A footnote processed in m:footnote-number mode renders the footnote number (or other symbol) associated with that footnote.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Perhaps unsurprisingly, footnote elements are processed in m:footnotes. On the first pass, they’re rendered inline with appropriate footnote markers. The “chunk cleanup” pass moves them to an appropriate location.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: All “block” elements that have a title (or another feature that constitutes a title) are processed in the m:generate-titlepage mode to generate their “title page”. Don’t be mislead by the term “title page”. For many elements, the title page consists of nothing more than a single header element.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode produces the “headline” title for an element. This generally appears in the text where the element is formatted, but may also occur in the table of contents, the index, and other places.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Produce the label for a headline title

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-label mode is used to generate the label in a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-label-separator mode is used to generate the separator that follows a label in a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-number mode is used to generate the number in a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-number-separator mode is used to generate the number separator in a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-prefix mode is used to generate any text that should precede the text of a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-suffix mode is used to generate any text that should follow the text of a headline.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:headline-title mode is used to format the title element in a headline.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determine the syntax highlighting options for an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: A verbatim element that will be syntax highlighted is processed in this mode to determine the options for the syntax highlighter. The template must return a map. The default template returns the language attribute if one is present.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Add script elements to the end of a document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: One way to assure that JavaScript will only be invoked by the user agent after the DOM tree has been constructed is to put the script elements for that code at the end of the file.

The root element of each result document is formatted once in the m:html-body-script mode. Any elements constructed in this mode will be added to the end of the HTML body. The built-in implementation does nothing; this mode exists as an extensibility point. See also m:html-head-script.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The m:html-head mode is used to produce the head element. This should include all of the metadata, links, scripts, etc. necessary to render the document correctly.
It is not supposed to be necessary to override this template. You can customize what is produced with the m:html-head-script, m:html-head-links, and m:html-head-last modes.
The order of elements produced in the head is:

listitem.para: Elements generated by the stylesheets automatically (title, scripts, links, and other elements).
Elements generated in m:html-head-script mode.
Elements generated in m:html-head-links mode.
Elements in the HTML namespace that are in the source document’s info.
Elements generated in m:html-head-last mode.

refsection.para: In addition, elements generated in m:html-body-script occur near the end of the HTML body element.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Add elements to the end of the head of a document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Any elements constructed in m:html-head-last mode will be added to the very end of the HTML head element. The built-in implementation does nothing; this mode exists as an extensibility point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Add link elements to the head of a document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Any elements constructed in m:html-head-links mode will be added to the HTML head element. The built-in implementation does nothing; this mode exists as an extensibility point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Add link elements to the head of a document

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Any elements constructed in m:html-head-script mode will be added to the HTML head element. The built-in implementation does nothing; this mode exists as an extensibility point.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing HTML table elements

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Where DocBook uses the HTML table model, it copies the definitions of the table elements (and the attributes on those elements) from HTML. The m:htmltable mode simply copies those elements and attributes to the result. When processing the contents of table cells, processing switches back to m:docbook mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating divisions in an index

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Index processing, that is, the process of generating an index, involves collecting all of the indexterms together, collating them, and rendering them.
The terms are grouped alphabetically and each group is processed in the m:index-div mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating primary index entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When generating an index, each distinct indexterm is processed in m:index-primary mode to output its primary entry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating secondary index entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When generating an index, each distinct secondary indexterm is processed in m:index-secondary mode to output its secondary entry.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When generating an index, each indexterm that defines a “see” index cross-reference is processed in m:index-see mode to output the cross-reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating index “see also” entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When generating an index, each indexterm that defines a “see also” index cross-reference is processed in m:index-seealso mode to output the cross-reference.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating index tertiary entries

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When generating an index, each distinct tertiary indexterm is processed in m:index-tertiary mode to output its tertiary entry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing funcsynopsis elements in the “K&R” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The funcsynopsis element has several possible renderings. This mode is used when the “K&R” style of rendering has been selected and a non-tabular layout is being used.

See also: m:kr-table, m:ansi, m:ansi-table, funcsynopsis-default-stylevariablefuncsynopsis-default-style, funcsynopsis-table-thresholdvariablefuncsynopsis-table-threshold, and funcsynopsis-trailing-punctuationvariablefuncsynopsis-trailing-punctuation.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode is used to process the parameters of a funcsynopsis in th K&R style. See funcsynopsis-default-styleparamfuncsynopsis-default-style.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing funcsynopsis elements in the “K&R” style

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The funcsynopsis element has several possible renderings. This mode is used when the “K&R” style of rendering has been selected and a table will be used for layout.

See also: m:kr, m:ansi, m:ansi-table, funcsynopsis-default-stylevariablefuncsynopsis-default-style, funcsynopsis-table-thresholdvariablefuncsynopsis-table-threshold, and funcsynopsis-trailing-punctuationvariablefuncsynopsis-trailing-punctuation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing function arguments in a table

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When the tabular presentation of a “K&R” funcsynopsis is being generated, this mode is used to process the function arguments.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: DocBook allows xlink:href to appear on most elements. All inline elements are processed in m:link mode to add a link around them if they specify an xlink:href.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating a list of equations

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If lists-of-equationsparamlists-of-equations is true, then a list of equations will be generated. This mode is used to process the equation elements (if any) to produce that list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating a list of examples

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If lists-of-examplesparamlists-of-examples is true, then a list of examples will be generated. This mode is used to process the example elements (if any) to produce that list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating a list of figures

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If lists-of-figuresparamlists-of-figures is true, then a list of figures will be generated. This mode is used to process the figure elements (if any) to produce that list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating a list of procedures

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If lists-of-proceduresparamlists-of-procedures is true, then a list of procedures will be generated. This mode is used to process the procedure elements (if any) to produce that list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating a list of tables

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: If lists-of-tablesparamlists-of-tables is true, then a list of tables will be generated. This mode is used to process the table elements (if any) to produce that list.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When a productionset is being formatted, the m:production-number mode is used to produce the prodution numbers.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: All of the profile processing (see ) is done in this mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Calculate the Pygments options for an element

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When the Pygments syntax highlighter is being used, every element that will be highlighted is processed in this mode to generate options for the Pygments process.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode to generate a “list” presentation of revhistory

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The revhistory element can be rendered as a list or a table (see revhistory-styleparamrevhistory-style). The m:revhistory-list mode is used to render it as a list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode to generate a “table” presentation of revhistory

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The revhistory element can be rendered as a list or a table (see revhistory-styleparamrevhistory-style). The m:revhistory-table mode is used to render it as a list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Process a segmentedlist as a table

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Segmented lists can be presented in either a list format or a table format. If the tabular format is selected, the segmentedlist is processed in this mode to generate the table.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing segment titles in a segment

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: In a segmentedlist, each segtitle is processed once for each segment. This processing occurs in the m:segtitle-in-seg mode.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating the mark for a synopfragementref

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The synopfragment element allows a synopsis (for example a cmdsynopsis) to move common fragments out-of-line. The location where these fragments occur in the primary synopsis is indicated with a synopfragmentref. The stylesheets will generate a mark, analogous to the marks used for footnotes or callouts, to connect the reference to the fragment. The fragment will be processed in m:synopfragment-bug to produce that mark.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for processing programming language synopses

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: The elements of class, method, and field synopses are processed in this mode.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: This mode is used to format titles when they appear in headlines or cross references.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Format elements for the title page

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Elements that appear on the title page are processed in this mode to produce the text that will appear on the title page.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When formatting personal names in a style that requires converting a name to upper case (see ), this mode is used to generate the upper-case name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mode for generating tables of contents

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Elements are processed in m:toc when automatically constructing a Table of Contents (or, more generally, any list of elements).

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: When an element appears in the Table of Contents (or other list of titles), it is formatted in this mode to produce the entry in the list.

The intrinsic size of an object is it’s actual size, measured in absolute units, usually pixels. The stylesheets rely on extension functions to obtain the intrinsic size of objects; if the extension functions aren’t available or the image format is not recognized, no intrinsic size will be known.

In this guide, the term “object” is used to refer generally to any image, video, or audio media element. They have a width and a height but no useful internal structure from the perspective of the stylesheets.

Processing instructions (see ) have no internal structure. The stylesheets interrogate the dbdb processing instruction processing instruction to determine formatting properties for a number of different elements.

In order to make it easy to consistently specify different properties, the value of the processing instruction is parsed as if it contained attributes. These pseudo-attributes must consist of a name, followed by “=”, followed by a quoted string.

XPath defines a boolean type, xs:boolean, that is either true or false. But for the purpose of passing parameters to the stylesheet at runtime, whether it’s from the command line, from a configuration file, or through some other means, it’s often more convenient to pass string values. This saves the user from having to use whatever extra syntactic mechanisms would be required to identify the type of the variable.
To this end, many “boolean” parameters are actually strings. A string value is true if it consists of one of the strings “true”, “yes”, or “1”.

A Clark name is a way of unambiguously representing a qualified name (see ) as a string. It consists of the namespace name in curly braces followed immediately by the local name. For example, the Clark name for the DocBook para element is: “{http://docbook.org/ns/docbook}para”.
